Research Paper Nitrogen-doped porous carbon materials supported bimetallic PdFe nanoparticles for the highly active reduction of 4-nitrophenol and olefin hydrogenation Zilong Pan Visualization Software Methodology Formal analysis 1 Maoling Pan Writing – original draft Validation Resources Methodology Formal analysis Data curation 1 Yingxin Shen Software Methodology Formal analysis Jie Dong Visualization Software Methodology Chunmei Song Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization Validation ⁎ Kun Huang Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization Validation ⁎ School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, 500N, Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200241, China School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering East China Normal University 500N, Dongchuan Road Shanghai 200241 China School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, 500N, Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200241, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. In this study, nitrogen-doped porous carbon-loaded PdFe alloy catalysts are prepared by in situ pyrolytic reduction strategy using covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) material as precursors. Due to the large specific surface area, multi-stage porous structure and the intermetallic synergistic interaction, the obtained Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 exhibits remarkable catalysis activity for the reduction reaction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) with a turnover frequency (TOF) as high as 2102 min-1, which represents the highest frequency reported to date. In addition, Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 also displays a superior effect on the olefin hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, the catalyst can retain 87.3% of its initial catalytic activity after six recycling cycles, which suggests its remarkable stability and potential for practical applications. Graphical abstract A simply synthesis of N-doped porous carbon supported bimetallic PdFe nanoparticles for the highly active reduction of 4-nitrophenol and olefin hydrogenation is reported for the first time. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen-doped porous carbon Covalent triazine frameworks PdFe alloy catalysts 4-Nitrophenol reduction Olefin hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rapid economic development has resulted in the extensive use of dyes, pigments, explosives, and pesticides in industrial processes. Especially, the discharge of numerous nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) have caused significant water pollution [1–3]. Among these NACs, 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) is of particular concern due to its high toxicity, chemically stable and soluble in water, making its removal from wastewater to be a significant challenge in natural environments [4–6]. A variety of techniques have been employed to treat 4-NP in water, including adsorption [7], electroflocculation [8], microbial degradation [9], photodegradation [10], and catalytic reduction [11]. Among the aforementioned methods, catalytic reduction of 4-NP to 4-aminophenol (4-AP) represents the most suitable approach for the conversion of organic pollutants into value-added intermediate compounds [12]. 4-AP is utilized as a primary material for the manufacture of cosmetics, organic dyes, aromatic amines, analgesic and antipyretic pharmaceuticals [13], and is also a crucial component in the production of developers, corrosion inhibitors, and anticorrosive lubricants [14]. The reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP is typically supported by NaBH4 as the reducing agent. The reduction potentials (4-NP/4-AP, −0.76 V and H3BO3/BH4 -, −1.33 V) indicate that the reaction can proceed thermodynamically [15,16]. However, the high kinetic barrier between 4-NP- and BH4 -, mutually repulsive charged negative ions produced upon hydrolysis of sodium borohydride, necessitates the use of an effective catalyst to facilitate the reduction process [17]. Accordingly, the development of a reusable, inexpensive and highly active catalyst for the catalytic reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP is of significant challenge. The catalytic reduction of 4-NP by sodium borohydride in the presence of metal catalysts has been demonstrated to be a cost-effective and environmentally friendly method [18]. To date, numerous noble metal catalysts (e.g. Ag, Pd, and Au) have demonstrated remarkable efficacy in the reduction of 4-NP [19–21], largely due to their distinctive catalytic properties, including surface plasmon resonance, quantum confinement effects, and negative Fermi energy levels [22]. However, their scarcity and high cost restrict their widespread application [23]. In contrast to monometallic catalysts, bimetallic nanoparticles have unique chemical and physical properties attributed to the synergistic effect of the two metals [24]. For instance, bimetallic nanoparticles (BNPs) synthesized by integrating non-noble metallic elements (Co, Fe, Ni, and Cu) into noble metal matrices not only reduce the cost of the hybridized bimetallic materials but also allow for a much higher catalytic performance due to synergistic interactions and electronic properties [25]. For example, Ismail et al. reported the synthesis of bimetallic nanoparticles supported on ginger rhizome powder using the simple adsorption method. The prepared Cu-Ag/GP and Cu-Ni/GP catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity for the reduction of nitrophenols and organic contaminants [26]. However, BNPs are prone to agglomeration or passivation, and the synthesis conditions are often harsh, which significantly impedes the widespread application of bimetallic nanocatalysts [27]. Currently, researchers have gradually attempted to improve the catalytic activity of bimetallic nanocatalysts and avoid their agglomeration or passivation by placing metal nanoparticles on stable carriers, including activated carbon [28], zeolite [29], nanotubes [30], organic coating [31] and metal-organic skeletons [32]. The selection of an appropriate carrier material is of great importance in the reduction process, as the stability and reactivity of bimetallic catalysts are largely dependent on the properties of the carrier surface [33,34]. Among various carriers, nitrogen-doped porous carbon materials (N-PCM) have received worldwide attention in recent years owing to the similar atomic radii of nitrogen and carbon, which changes the physicochemical properties of porous carbon materials such as the acid−base property, wettability and electronic structure, making active N sites to enhance electron density, promote the interaction between metal and support [35]. As far as the preparation of N-PCM, the in-situ introduction of N atoms by the pyrolysis of nitrogen-containing porous organic networks is an effective way to get the homogeneous introduction of N atoms in the carbon material. Covalent triazine-based frameworks (CTFs) as a kind of classic nitrogen-containing porous organic network are applied to many fields including catalysis [36], gas adsorption and storage [37], and the utilization as adsorbent materials [38]. Specially, on account of their super high thermal stability, large surface area and high N content, CTFs are excellent precursor materials for preparing N-PCM. Compared to the traditional synthetic ways of CTFs produced under high temperature or the presence of strong Bronsted acid catalyst, our group have recently developed a mild one-step pathway to produce CTFs by Friedel-Crafts alkylation, and the obtained CTFs can further used as precursor to produce metal-loading N-PCM [39]. In this study, the electron-rich compound carbazole and the electrophilic cyanuric trichloride were selected as monomers for the preparation of CTFs via the Friedel-Crafts reaction. Subsequently, the simultaneous impregnation of palladium and iron salts into the CTFs was conducted. The N-PCM loaded PdFe alloy catalysts were obtained through an in situ pyrolytic reduction strategy. The high N content of the triazine skeleton ensured the uniform and stable distribution of the metal nanoparticles on the carrier. The combination of a large specific surface area and intermetallic synergistic effect, coupled with the mild H2O2 post-treatment, afforded the Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 remarkable advantages in catalyzing the reduction reaction of 4-NP. Furthermore, the catalyst demonstrated remarkable efficacy in the hydrogenation of the C=C bond. Based on these findings, this paper proposes a simple and effective method for the synthesis of stable bimetallic alloy catalysts with significant potential for practical applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Unless otherwise noted, all materials were used as purchased without further processing. Sinopharm (China), Adamas Reagent Ltd., Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd., and 3A Chemicals supplied all commercially available chemicals and reagents. Sinopharm (China) also provided other analytically pure solvents, including ethanol, methanol, chloroform, and acetone. The water used in this work was deionized water. Styrene (99 %, Aldrich) was filtered over basic alumina before use. 2.2 Characterization methods Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterizations. TEM was obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100F instrument working at 200 kV. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterizations. The XRD patterns of the samples were collected using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å) operated at 35 kV and 25 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. XPS measurements were performed using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer, equipped with an Al Kα radiation X-ray source. All the collected spectra were calibrated with contaminated C 1s peak at 284.8 eV and were analyzed using Avantage software. N2 adsorption and desorption experiments. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) surface area, N2 sorption isotherms (77 K), and pore size distributions were measured using Quantachrome Autosorb IQ specific surface area and porosity analyzer. The BET surface areas and the micropore surface areas were determined by the BET equation and the t-plot equation, respectively. The pore size distributions were analyzed by DFT methods via the adsorption branch. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) characterizations. The Pd and Fe contents in different samples were determined with ICP-OES on the Optima 8300. Standard curve fitting was obtained by diluting the commercially available samples. Raman spectra measurements. Raman spectra were collected on a Thermo DXR instrument with a λ = 532 nm excitation laser. UV–visible absorption spectra (UV-visible). All the reaction solutions were diluted with deionized water and their UV–visible absorption spectra were measured by SOPTOP UV2400. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR). 1 H NMR spectra were acquired by testing on a Bruker AVANCE III 500 instrument, operating at 500 MHz. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR). Infrared spectra of the sample was obtained using a Thermo NICOLET iS50. Gas chromatography (GC). The reaction solutions were analyzed using a Timex 7900 GC instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) for quantification of individual products, and N2 was utilized as the carrier gas. 2.3 Catalysts preparation 2.3.1 Synthesis of carbazole-covalent triazine microporous polymer (CCTMP) A mixture of 2.5 g of carbazole and 2.8 g of cyanuric chloride was added to 250 mL of CHCl3, then 9.7 g of catalyst anhydrous FeCl3 was dispersed into the above solution and the mixture was reacted for 24 h at 80 °C. After the reaction was completed, a solid crude product was obtained by filtration. The crude product was washed with 1 mol/L dilute hydrochloric acid-ethanol aqueous solution to remove iron ions, and then the product CCTMP was dried under vacuum at 80 °C overnight. Yield = 2.76 g. 2.3.2 Synthesis of N-doped porous carbon loaded palladium-iron nanoparticles (PdFe@N-PCM) 500 mg of CCTMP was homogeneously dispersed in 15 mL of acetone, and then 25 mg of Pd(OAc)2 and 50 mg of FeCl3·6H2O were dissolved in 5 mL of acetone, and the solution was added dropwise to the suspension. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h, after which the acetone was removed by evaporation. The solid was placed in a tube furnace and subjected to pyrolysis at 700 °C for two hours under N2 atmosphere. 15 mL of H2O2 was added to the product and stirred for 12 h at 25 °C. Then the mixture was filtered to give the final product, Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2, with a measured Pd content of 2.085 wt % and Fe content of 2.255 wt % by ICP analysis. Yield = 298 mg. To investigate the influence of diverse variables on the catalytic characteristics of the materials, a range of catalysts with varying bimetallic ratios and carbonization temperatures were synthesized. Pd1Fe1@N-PCM-700-H2O2 (loaded with 5 % Pd(OAc)2 and 5 % FeCl3·6H2O), Pd1Fe5@N-PCM-700-H2O2 (loaded with 5 % Pd(OAc)2 and 25 % FeCl3·6H2O), Pd1@N-PCM-700-H2O2 (loaded with only 5 % Pd(OAc)2) and (loaded with only 10 % FeCl3·6H2O) Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 were prepared by the same process as above. Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-600-H2O2 and Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-800-H2O2 represent carbonization temperatures of 600 °C and 800 °C, respectively. 2.4 Catalytic experiment details 2.4.1 The reduction of 4-nitrophenol in aqueous solution In a typical reaction run, 10 mL of 4-NP solution (60 mM) was mixed with 60 mmol of NaBH4 and 5 mg of catalyst in a 50 mL round-bottom flask, with stirring. The reduction of 4-NP was monitored by UV–Vis spectroscopy until the reaction mixture ceased to exhibit a coloration. To test the pervasiveness of the nitro reduction reaction, 0.6 mmol of nitroaromatics was dissolved in a solution of water and ethanol (4:6, v/v) in a flask. Subsequently, 60 mmol of NaBH4 and 5 mg of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 were added to the aforementioned solution, which was then stirred. The reaction was monitored at regular intervals by thin-layer chromatography. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by filtration, and the composition of the final product in the filtrate was further analyzed by GC. After each reaction, the mixture was subjected to centrifugation, and the supernatant was analyzed via UV-visible spectroscopy. The collected catalyst was washed with ethanol three times and used for the next cycling tests. The turnover frequency (TOF) calculations [40]. TOF value was defined as moles of 4-NP converted per mole of exposed surface metal per min as follows: TOF = n conversion of 4 − NP / ( n total Pd + Fe × D × t ) Where is the moles of 4-NP converted, n total Pd + Fe , t and D represent the total moles of Pd and Fe, reaction time and dispersion, respectively. 2.4.2 The hydrogenation of allylacetic acid In a typical reaction, 2.5 mmol of allylacetic acid and 5 mg of catalyst were dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol in a 25 mL reaction flask. The air within the flask was displaced on three occasions with H2, a hydrogen-filled balloon was then placed over the flask to agitate the contents for a specified period at room temperature. The reaction was monitored at regular intervals through thin-layer chromatography. Upon completion of the reaction, the solid catalyst was filtered and separated. The filtrate was spun to remove the solvent, and deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide was added. The conversion was then analyzed by nuclear magnetic hydrogen spectroscopy. The catalytic reactions of 1-octene, 1–18 alkene and 9-vinylcarbazole were conducted in a stainless steel intermittent reactor within a Teflon-lined tube (50 mL). 12.5 mg of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2, 0.5 mmol of raw material and 10 mL of solvent were loaded into the reactor. Subsequently, the reaction kettle was purged with purified H2 (99.999 % purity) five times and pressurized to 4 MPa with H2 before being transferred to an oil bath at 80 °C to stir the reaction. The conversion was identified through the use of GC or nuclear magnetic hydrogen spectroscopy at the end of the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts Firstly, The carbazole-covalent triazine microporous polymer (CCTMP) was synthesized through the Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction by employing carbazole and cyanuric chloride as the initial monomers (Fig. 1 ). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed to verify the successful synthesis of CCTMP (Fig. S1). The NH oscillatory peak near 3360 cm-1 was attributed to carbazole, while the C=N oscillatory peaks near 1495 and 1350 cm-1 were assigned to CTMP. These results demonstrated that the two monomers was successfully cross-linked. Subsequently, acetone solutions of Pd(OAc)2 and FeCl3·6H2O were added into CCTMP, which exhibited uniform and stable loading of metal ions due to the robust interactions between the N elements in the triazine skeleton and the metal ions. Ultimately, N-doped porous carbon materials loaded with PdFe alloy nanoparticles (Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2) were produced through in situ high-temperature carbonization reduction and a mild H2O2 post-treatment process. The morphology of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 was observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As illustrated in Fig. 2 , the carriers exhibited an irregular porous sheet structure, and the bimetallic nanoparticles were uniformly distributed within the microporous carbon sheets. One hundred nanoparticles were randomly selected for particle size measurement, with an average particle size of approximately 9.02 nm calculated. To further analyze the composition of the alloyed nanoparticles on Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and related elemental distribution mapping were carried out for characterization. As shown in Figs. 2b and S2, the lattice stripe spacing of the nanoparticles is measured at 0.212 nm, which aligns with the crystalline surface of the PdFe alloy (111) as documented in the literature. This finding indicates that the nanoparticles exist in the form of an alloy. Furthermore, the distribution of the elements in the catalyst is exhibited in Fig. S2. The uniform distribution of Pd and Fe elements on the same metal nanoparticles suggests that they are PdFe alloys rather than single metal nanoparticles. Furthermore, the uniform distribution of N in the hollow nanospheres can also well prevent the agglomeration of the PdFe nanoparticles, thus improving the activity of the catalyst. The presence of Pd and Fe as alloy on the carrier was further confirmed through powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Fig. 3 a illustrates the characteristic peak at 44.7° for the Fe-only monometallic catalyst (Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2), which corresponds to the Fe (110) facet. The peaks at 35.6 °and 62.5 °correspond to the Fe3O4 (311) and (440) facets, respectively. It can be inferred that this is primarily due to the partial oxidation of Fe in the presence of air. The monometallic catalyst containing only Pd (Pd1@N-PCM-700-H2O2) exhibits three diffraction peaks at 40.1 °, 46.3 °and 67.2 ° These peaks correspond to the Pd (111), Pd (200), and Pd (220) crystal planes, respectively. The bimetallic alloy catalyst (Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2) exhibits a prominent peak at 41.1°, correlating with the PdFe (111) crystallographic plane, and the characteristic peak at 69 °corresponds to the PdFe (220) crystallographic plane. This observation substantiates the formation of PdFe alloy. Furthermore, characteristic peaks at 35.6°, 44.4°, and 46.3° indicate that Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 also contains minor quantities of Fe3O4, Fe0 and Pd0. The Pd1Fe2 samples were subjected to Raman spectroscopy, and the results are presented in Fig. 3b. The G band at ∼1590 cm-1 indicates the degree of graphitization of the material, originating from the in-plane vibration of sp2 C atoms. The D band, observed at ∼1350 cm-1, is attributed to defects, vacancies, and sp2 distortion [41]. The intensity ratio of the two peak bands (ID/IG) can be used to characterize the degree of defects in a material. As the carbonization temperature of the material increases from 600 °C to 800 °C, the ID/IG ratio increases from 0.524 to 0.863, indicating that the degree of defects in the catalyst also increases. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of porous carbon carriers have been demonstrated to influence the catalytic performance of these materials significantly. Consequently, the pore structures of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700 and Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 were characterized by utilizing N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. As illustrated in Fig. 3c, the catalysts display type IV adsorption isotherms with markedly enhanced absorption at relatively low pressures (p/p0 < 0.01), indicating micropores within the structure, according to the IUPAC classification. The presence of H4-type hysteresis loops at relatively high pressures (p/p0 = 0.4–0.9) suggests the existence of additional mesoporous structures in this sample, as capillary condensation associated with mesoporous channels is a characteristic phenomenon of such materials. The pore size distribution obtained from nonlocal density flood theory (NLDFT) indicates that the pore sizes of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700 are primarily distributed at 0.74 nm and 51.5 nm (Fig. S3), which suggests that the porous material is predominantly microporous and macropores. The H2O2 post-treatment resulted in the partial removal of the carbon layer, which enriched the pore structure of the material and led to an observed increase in the specific surface area from 421.25 to 486.41 m2/g for Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2. As demonstrated in Fig. 3d, the pore sizes of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 are predominantly distributed at 0.80 nm and 0.85 nm, indicating that the porous material is predominantly composed of micropores. Furthermore, the presence of pores measuring 1.51 nm, 3.06 nm, 3.83 nm and 9.35 nm is observed, thereby substantiating the existence of a multistage pore structure that is conducive to the mass transfer of substances during the reaction [42]. To provide a more detailed description of the catalyst composition, Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700 and Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 were subjected to X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. As illustrated in Fig. 4 and Table S1, the material is predominantly composed of five elements: C, N, O, Pd and Fe. The elemental contents of O, Pd and Fe increased significantly, and the elemental content of C decreased after the H2O2 treatment, confirming that the H2O2 treatment can effectively produce rich oxygenated functional groups and simultaneously remove the carbon layer covering the surface of PdFe alloy, thereby exposing more metal active sites [43–45]. This process promoted rapid contact and reaction between the PdFe alloy nanoparticles in the catalyst and the reactants. Fig. 4c shows that the C 1s peak is approximately 283.9 eV, which is characteristic of graphitic carbon species with sp2 hybridization. The N 1s spectrum exhibits three peaks at ∼398.6 eV, 400.1 eV, and 401.2 eV, which correspond to the N binding energy in pyridinic N, pyrrolic N and graphitic N in Fig. 4d, respectively. These observations corroborate the efficacy of the N-doping process on the material. The Pd 3d XPS spectra of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 (Fig. 4e) display Multiple species. The peaks at approximately 335.1 eV and 340.4 eV are attributed to Pd (0), while the peaks at 337.6 eV and 342.9 eV are indicative of Pd (II), which appears to lower binding energies shift compared with the Pd 3d binding energies of monometallic Pd, confirming the formation of PdFe alloy. As illustrated in Fig. 4f, two discrete bands are evident in the XPS spectrum of Fe 2p, corresponding to the low-energy (Fe 2p3/2) and high-energy (Fe 2p1/2) asymmetric bands resulting from spin-orbit splitting [46]. The Fe 2p peaks can be decomposed into two distinct components, with the characteristic peaks observed at 714.16 eV are attributed to Fe (0), while the peaks at 711 eV and 724 eV are attributed to Fe (II). The presence of Fe (II) can be partly attributed to incomplete pyrolysis of the material, leading to partial Fe3O4 production. Furthermore, the XPS spectra of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700 are presented in Fig. S4. These spectra demonstrate that while Pd (II), Fe (II), and Fe (III) are present, they are in relatively low amounts. This evidence suggests the surface oxidization of partial Pd (0) and Fe (0) nanoparticles in air and during H2O2 post-treatment. To investigate the optimal metal loading ratio of the materials and the synthesis temperature, catalysts with palladium and iron ratios of 1:0,1:1,1:2,1:5,0:2 and pyrolysis at 600 °C,700 °C and 800 °C, respectively, were designed in this paper. The catalytic hydrogenation of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) was monitored using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer in a specific wavelength range, to elucidate the effect of different catalysts. In the presence of catalysts, the intensity of the absorption peak at approximately 400 nm diminishes gradually, while the intensity of the new peak at approximately 300 nm increases over time. This suggests that the 4-NP is undergoing hydrogenation, resulting in the formation of 4-AP. The metal content was measured by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy and the results are shown in Table S2. The catalytic reduction of 4-NP is shown in Table 1 and Fig. 5 . In the course of the 4-NP reduction reaction catalyzed by Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700, the conversion of the substrate was observed to reach a maximum of 89.33 % after a reaction time of 24 h. However, following the treatment with H2O2, the activity of the catalyst underwent a substantial enhancement, resulting in the complete reduction of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 within a remarkably short span of 50 s. This phenomenon can be attributed to the fact that a significant proportion of the active metal nanoparticles became obscured by carbon deposits produced during the carbonization process. The subsequent reaction of H2O2 with the carbon layer led to the exposure of mass metal nanoparticles on the material surface. This development facilitated the rapid contact and reaction between the Pd-Fe metal and 4-NP within the catalyst. Subsequently, the catalytic performance of the catalysts was compared at different pyrolysis temperatures (600 °C and 800 °C). It was found that the activity of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-600-H2O2 was not very good, which may be caused by incomplete pyrolysis resulting in a low metal content. A comparison of the XRD plots of each catalyst with the PdFe standard card (PDF#00–002–1440) is shown in Figs. 3a and S5, and the catalytic activity of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-800-H2O2 is not as good as that of 700 °C, which is probably because the 2θ values of the catalysts move to a lower position after the temperature was increased, which represents the expansion of the PdFe alloys’ crystal lattice towards the transformation back to zero-valent Pd and zero-valent iron tendency to move. In the subsequent experiment, the temperature of 700 °C was identified as the optimal carbonation temperature. To this end, a series of catalysts were designed, incorporating varying Pd-Fe ratios. These catalysts were synthesized by meticulously controlling the addition of Pd(OAc)2 and FeCl3·6H2O during synthesis. This approach enabled the exploration of the most effective Pd: Fe ratio for the 4-NP reduction reaction. The monometallic catalysts, Pd1@N-PCM-700-H2O2 and Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2, both necessitated 24 h or more to achieve complete conversion of the response. In contrast, Pd1Fe1@N-PCM-700-H2O2 resulted in the formation of PdFe alloy; however, the actual metal content was inadequate, leading to a suboptimal catalytic effect. Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 exhibited superior performance compared to Pd1Fe5@N-PCM-700-H2O2 can be attributed to the forming of a greater number of PdFe alloys by Pd1Fe2, resulting in bimetallic synergy. The activity of each catalyst was assessed in terms of turnover frequency (TOF) values, with the most effective Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 reaching as high as 2102 min-1, which is considerably higher than a significant number of literature values in recent years (Table 2 and Fig. 6 ). Here, palladium serves as the hydrogen activation center which efficiently dissociate hydrogen molecules and adsorb active hydrogen atoms to form [Pd-H] species. In the palladium-iron alloy formed through high-temperature carbonization, the lower electronegativity of iron atoms increases the electron density of palladium atoms and cause the heterolytic adsorption of abundant hydrogen. Meanwhile, iron atoms as Lewis acid sites can strongly adsorb the nitro structure in the substrate through the affinity with oxygen atoms, which can reduce the bond energy of the nitrogen-oxygen double bond and promote the hydrogenation reaction. Additionally, the catalyst with hydrogen peroxide post-treatment contains more oxygen-containing functional groups, which improve the hydrophilicity of the catalyst and promote the enrichment of substrate molecules at the active sites of the catalyst, leading to the superior catalytic activity of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2. To determine the reusability and stability of the catalyst, the recovered Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 was subjected to a three-stage washing process, comprising water and ethanol, following each experimental run. It is noteworthy that even after six cycles, a conversion of 87.3 % was still achieved (Fig. 5g), indicating that Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 is highly stable in catalyzing the 4-NP reduction reaction. The catalysts that had undergone multiple cycles were subjected to TEM and XRD analysis (Fig. S6). Despite repeated cycling, the metal nanoparticles exhibited no agglomeration, retaining their alloyed state. These observations further proved the stability of the PdFe alloy loading on the carrier. To ascertain the universality of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2, a series of hydrogenation reduction reactions were conducted on a range of nitroaromatics. Given that nitroaromatics are essentially insoluble in water, the reduction reaction was conducted in a solution of H2O/EtOH rather than in pure water. As illustrated in Table 3 , the data demonstrated that all of these nitroaromatics could be efficiently hydrogenated in the presence of the catalyst to produce the corresponding aminoaromatics with the high yields. Moreover, the influence of the catalyst on the hydrogenation of 4-pentanoic acid was further examined, and the results are presented in Table 4 . The Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 not only exhibits effective reduction of 4-NP but also displays superior hydrogenation capabilities for 4-pentanoic acid compared to other catalysts. To test the universality of the catalyst, styrene, 1-octene, 1-octadecene, and N-vinyl carbazole were selected as reaction substrates (Table S3). The results demonstrated that Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 not only catalyzes N=O bond reduction efficiently but also exhibits a superior effect on the hydrogenation reaction of the C=C bond. 4 Conclusion The nitrogen-doped porous carbon-loaded PdFe alloy catalyst was successfully prepared through a combination of in situ pyrolysis strategy and mild H2O2 post-treatment using CCTMP as precursors. The resulting Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 exhibited excellent catalytic activity for the reduction of a series of nitroaromatics and the hydrogenation of C=C bond at a ratio of 1:2 for Pd and Fe salts and a pyrolysis temperature of 700 °C. In the reduction of 4-NP, the TOF of Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 reach to 2102 min-1, which is considerably higher than that of numerous metal-based catalysts in recent years and represents the highest reported performance to date. The strong electronic interaction between Pd and Fe creates a synergistic effect and improves PdFe alloy catalytic activity. Moreover, the catalyst exhibits remarkable cycling stability, which can be attributed to the stabilizing influence of nitrogen atom on the carrier, effectively preventing the leakage of the alloy throughout the catalytic process. coredata.dc:description: In this study, nitrogen-doped porous carbon-loaded PdFe alloy catalysts are prepared by in situ pyrolytic reduction strategy using covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) material as precursors. Due to the large specific surface area, multi-stage porous structure and the intermetallic synergistic interaction, the obtained Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 exhibits remarkable catalysis activity for the reduction reaction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) with a turnover frequency (TOF) as high as 2102 min-1, which represents the highest frequency reported to date. In addition, Pd1Fe2@N-PCM-700-H2O2 also displays a superior effect on the olefin hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, the catalyst can retain 87.3% of its initial catalytic activity after six recycling cycles, which suggests its remarkable stability and potential for practical applications.

coredata.dc:title: Nitrogen-doped porous carbon materials supported bimetallic PdFe nanoparticles for the highly active reduction of 4-nitrophenol and olefin hydrogenation
